definition: Peng Dehuai (1898-1974), top communist general, subsequently politician and politburo member, disgraced after attacking Mao's failed policies in 1959, and died after extensive persecution during the Cultural Revolution
surname Peng
Germany/German/abbr. for 德國|德国[De2 guo2]
virtue/goodness/morality/ethics/kindness/favor/character/kind
bosom/heart/mind/to think of/to harbor in one's mind/to conceive (a child)
surname Huai

sentences.english: However, Huili Conference had influenced Zhang Wentian and Peng Dehuai to some extent.
sentences.chinese: 會理會議也給張聞天和彭德懷帶來一定影響。

sentences.english: In Manchuria , Peng Dehuai was furious when he learned this.
sentences.chinese: 在中國東北，彭德懷得知此事之後大爲惱火。

sentences.english: As far as I could learn, P'eng slept an average of only four or five hours a night.
sentences.chinese: 就我所知，彭德懷每天晚上平均只睡四五小時。

sentences.english: With the issuing of Comrade Peng Dehuai's letter, however, there was a change of direction.
sentences.chinese: 彭德懷同志的信一發下來，就轉變風向了。

sentences.english: P'eng suddenly called out to his panting staff and me.
sentences.chinese: 彭德懷突然向他氣喘吁吁的部下和我叫道。

definition: Military Commission of the Communist Party Central Committee
Autumn Harvest Uprising (1927), insurrection in Hunan and Jiangxi provinces led by Mao Zedong
Liu Shaoqi (1898-1969), Chinese communist leader, a martyr of the Cultural Revolution
Luo Ronghuan (1902-1963), Chinese communist military leader
He Long (1896-1969), important communist military leader, died from persecution during the Cultural Revolution
Communist International or Comintern (1919-1943), also known as the Third International 第三國際|第三国际[Di4 san1 Guo2 ji4]
Chen Jiongming (1878-1933), a leading warlord of Guangdong faction, defeated in 1925 and fled to Hong Kong
Zhang Guotao (1897-1979), Chinese communist leader in the 1920s and 1930s, defected to Guomindang in 1938
commander-in-chief/top military commander for a country or theater of operations
Xiang Ying (1898-1941), communist general involved in forming the New Fourth Army 新四軍, killed in 1941 during the New Fourth Army incident 皖南事变
Chen Yi (1901-1972), communist general and politician, Marshal of PLA from 1955, Mayor of Shanghai in 1950s, PRC foreign minister 1958-1972
Yang Shangkun (1907-1998), former president of PRC and military leader
United Front (either of the two alliances between the Guomindang and the Communist Party, 1923-1927 and 1937-1945)
Zunyi conference of January 1935 before the Long March
(military) Chief of Staff
Nanchang Uprising, 1st August 1927, the beginning of military revolt by the Communists in the Chinese Civil War
